title: 114_hr3502
content: The "Tribal Nutrition Improvement Act of 2015" may be cited as such. It includes provisions for universal meal service in Native American areas. The Tribal Nutrition Improvement Act of 2015 includes provisions for universal meal service in Native American areas, allowing alternatives to daily meal counting, annual applications for meal eligibility, and universal meal service. The Tribal Nutrition Improvement Act of 2015 allows alternatives for universal meal service in Native American areas, including serving all meals to students at no cost and covering excess costs from non-Federal sources. The Tribal Nutrition Improvement Act of 2015 allows for demonstration projects to test alternatives for universal meal service in Native American areas, including serving all meals to students at no cost and waiving certain requirements related to meal counting and eligibility determinations. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to define the term 'State' to include various regions. Additionally, the Summer Food Service Program for Children is addressed in the following section. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include Indian tribes in the Summer Food Service Program for Children. Administrative and start-up funds are also addressed. Section 7(c) of the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to allow Indian tribes to administer certain food programs under the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act. An adjustment in administrative funds will be made if an Indian tribe agrees to take on this responsibility. The Secretary will adjust administrative funds for Indian tribes administering food programs under the Child Nutrition Act, with start-up funds ranging from $10,000 to $100,000 per fiscal year. The Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to define the term 'State' to include the 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, the Northern Mariana Islands, and Indian tribes.
